Seeing the asura kings and even the non-Buddhist brÄhmaá¹‡as receiving the Buddha's predictions, they gave rise to unprecedented admiration, thinking:
The Buddha's voice is beautiful and clear, and all who hear it in the world rejoice.
At that time, King Åšuddhodana, having just seen the TathÄgata, was filled with love and affection.
At that time, the World-Honored One, knowing what his father, the king, was thinking, said to him:
Great King!
The Dharma I teach is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end. Its meaning is profound and subtle, pure and singular, and its practice of austerity is perfect.
What I am now expounding is the Dharma door of distinguishing the six elements and their various states.
King, listen attentively!
Think about it well!
At that time, King Åšuddhodana said to the Buddha:
Excellent!
World-Honored One!
I joyfully wish to hear and will proclaim, uphold, and faithfully accept it for me.
The Buddha said:
Great King!
Thus, the six elements, six bases of contact, and eighteen mental observations are the conditions for the birth of a brahmin.
What are the six elements?
Namely, the earth element, water element, fire element, wind element, space element, and consciousness element.
What are the six bases of contact?

It means that the eye base of contact sees forms, the ear base of contact hears sounds, the nose base of contact smells fragrances, the tongue base of contact tastes flavors, the body base of contact personally experiences tactile objects, and the mind base of contact knows mental phenomena.
What are the eighteen mental observations? It means that when the eye sees forms, if there is delight, if there is sorrow, or if there is equanimity;
Each of these six faculties encounters those three, such as delight, and so on. This is called the eighteen mental observations.
Great King!
What is the internal earth element?
It refers to the hard and rough things produced in the internal body, such as hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, and bones.
If the internal earth element is not produced, it also does not cease, and then there is no accumulation of activity.
Great King!
At that time, if a woman, in her inner mind, thinks of a man as she wishes, and that man also feels affection, due to the union of the two, the kalala is born.
Moreover, it is not possible for something to be born through the union of similar thoughts;ğŸ”½it is not possible for two women;
it is not possible for two men;
it is also not possible for something to be born through the thoughts of this and that.
Because the self-body is unreal and not in accord with the characteristics.
How can this be said to be the nature of solidity?
Great King!
This solidity is established based on similarity, but in the end, this body will collapse, rot, and disperse, and only the cemetery will be its destination.
Where does this solidity come from?
It does not go to the four directions, above or below.
Great King!
The inner earth element should be known in this way.
Great King!
What is the solidity of the outer earth element? Like the palace of the Brahma King that first appeared in the world, made of great treasures;
And then the palaces of the Paranirmita-vaÅ›avartin gods appeared, all made of the seven treasures.
Great King!
If there were no earth element, where would that solidity come from?
And then the great earth formed, 84,000 yojanas thick and 60,000 yojanas wide;
And then the CakravÄá¸a and MahÄcakravÄá¸a mountains appeared, firmly abiding as one vajra;
It then grows into Mount Sumeru, Mount Yugandhara, Mount Äªá¹£Ädhara, Mount Khadiraka, up to the Black Mountains.
Thus, the trichiliocosm is formed in sequence, firm and stable.
If there were no earth element, where would this solidity come from?
Great King!

Moreover, when this earth element is about to be destroyed, whether burned by fire, flooded by water, or blown by wind, it is like burning ghee or oil, with raging flames until they become ashes and are no longer visible.
If flooded by water, it is like salt thrown into water, instantly dissolving and dispersing.
If blown by the fierce wind of the end times, at that time the trichiliocosm will be completely destroyed, leaving nothing behind.
Great King!
This external earth element, when arising, is originally empty, and when ceasing, is also empty. Because its intrinsic nature is empty, it has no male characteristics and no female characteristics;
It is only revealed by verbal expression.
In this way, the earth element and the nature of the earth element are both unobtainable, only the Buddha's right wisdom can understand it.
Great King!
What is the internal water element?
It refers to the internal water element in this body, which is the nature of moisture and so forth, such as saliva, fat, marrow, pus, blood, feces and urine.
Great King!

When one suddenly sees a loved one, tears flow from the eyes, or one is afflicted by suffering and tears flow, or one hears the profound Dharma with faith and tears flow, or one is blown by cold wind and tears flow.
From where does this water element come?
When the characteristics of water dry up, where does it go?

Up to when this realm is destroyed, a great black cloud rises, thirty-two layers thick, covering the trichiliocosm, and pours down a great rain, with drops as large as elephants, pouring day and night, continuing without interruption.
In this way, the water accumulates for fifty eons, filling up to the Brahma world.
Great King!
Where does this external water element come from?
Moreover, when this world is about to perish, two suns appear. When two suns appear, the small rivers and springs all dry up.
When three suns appear, the four rivers that flow out from the Anavatapta Lake also dry up.
When four suns appear, the water in the great ocean decreases by one yojana, or two or three, gradually decreasing to ten yojanas, or twenty yojanas, drying up in sequence to eighty yojanas.
Some water remains, either deep to the height of one tÄla tree, or deep to the chest, or deep to the hoofprint of a cow, or as little water as the surface of a finger.
At that time, the water in the great ocean is completely dried up, leaving nothing remaining.
Great King!

The characteristics of this water element, when arising, do not come from anywhere, and when ceasing, do not go anywhere. When arising, it is originally empty, and when ceasing, it is also empty. Because its intrinsic nature is empty, there are no male characteristics and no female characteristics, but are only revealed by verbal expressions.
In this way, the water element and the nature of the water element are both unobtainable, only the Buddha's right wisdom can understand it.
Great King!
What is the internal fire element of the body?

All that is appropriated by this body, warm and hot, chewed and eaten, matured and transformed, then causing it to be peaceful and harmonious, and entering the category of heat, is called the fire element.
What is the external fire element?
It refers to the warm and hot characteristics that are not appropriated.
If a person in the wilderness seeks for the conditions of fire, using mugwort, cow dung, or cotton to draw out and produce fire;
Or burning grass, trees, mountains, forests, villages, and other places, all are burned.
Great King!

This fire element has no coming when it arises, and no going when it ceases. When it arises, it is originally empty, and when it ceases, it is also empty. Because its intrinsic nature is empty, it is only revealed by words.
In this way, the fire element and the nature of the fire element are both unobtainable, only the Buddha's right wisdom can understand it.
Great King!
What are the characteristics of lightness and movement in the internal wind element?

This internal wind sometimes moves upwards, sometimes moves downwards, sometimes stays in the abdomen, sometimes in the sides or back, sometimes causes hemorrhoids, sometimes gathers to form lumps, sometimes splits like a knife, sometimes pricks like a needle, and the in-breath and out-breath pervade the limbs of the body.
What is the external wind element?

It refers to the wind that comes from the four directions, or violently rises to uproot trees, topple mountain peaks, or subtly rises to blow clothes and move tÄla trees, called the external wind element.
Great King!

This wind element, when arising, does not come from anywhere, and when ceasing, does not go anywhere. When arising, it is originally empty, and when ceasing, it is also empty. Because its intrinsic nature is empty, it has no male characteristics and no female characteristics, but is only indicated by verbal expressions.
Thus, this wind element and the nature of the wind element are both unobtainable, only the Buddha's right wisdom can understand it.
Great King!
What is the internal space element?
The skin, flesh, and blood that appear and increase within this body, apart from the nature of obstruction.
Namely, the eye sockets, ear holes, mouth, throat, and the passage for swallowing food and drink, which pass through the intestines and stomach and come out.
When the conditions of karma lead to the arising of the six sense bases, and after the sense bases arise, they surround the space element, this is called being included in the internal space element.
But where does that space element come from?
Moreover, if it is the unobstructed nature that appears externally, it is called the external space element.
Great King!
If form changes and decays, all is empty.
Why is this?
Because this realm of space is originally inexhaustible, it is peaceful and still, unmoving, just like nirvana, pervading everywhere without obstruction.
Great King!
It is like a person who digs a pond or a well on a high plain.
What do you think?
Where does the empty space in that pond or well come from?
The king said:
It comes from nowhere.
The Buddha said:
Great King!
Suppose that person were to fill it with soil again.
What do you think?
Where does the emptiness go?
The king said:
Emptiness goes nowhere.
Why is this?
Because this realm of space has no coming or going, it does not abide in the male form, nor is it the female form.
Great King!
The external space element is originally motionless, because its intrinsic nature is detached. It is only revealed by verbal expressions, except for the Buddha's right wisdom that can understand it.
Great King!
What is the realm of consciousness?
It is said that when the eye faculty is dominant, and it takes form and its manifest form as objects, it is called the eye-consciousness realm.
When the other five faculties take their own objects and establish themselves separately, they are called the five consciousness realms.
Moreover, this realm of consciousness does not cling to the faculties, does not abide in the objects, is neither internal nor external, nor in between the two.

However, this realm of consciousness, having cognized each and every object, immediately ceases and disappears. When arising, it does not come from anywhere, and when ceasing, it does not go anywhere.
Great King!

When consciousness arises, it is empty, and when it ceases, it is also empty, because its intrinsic nature is detached. It does not abide in the male form nor is it the female form, but is only revealed by verbal expressions.
In this way, the realm of consciousness and the nature of consciousness are both unobtainable, just as the Buddha's right wisdom can understand.
Great King!
What is the eye faculty?
It refers to the pure form created by the four great elements - the earth element, water element, fire element, and wind element.
If the earth element is pure, then the eye faculty is pure;
if the water, fire, and wind elements are pure, then the eye faculty is pure.
Why is this?
Because when the earth element is pure, the eye faculty can arise, but within this there is not a single dharma that can be obtained.
In this way, up to when the wind element is pure, the eye faculty can arise, but within this there is not a single dharma that can be obtained.
Why is this?
Because there is no controller, and because there is no creator.
It is just like nirvana, which is pure by nature.
Great King!
In this way, the eye faculty is individually sought but cannot be obtained.
Why is this?
The earth element is empty, and therefore the earth element is pure. Up to the wind element is empty, and therefore the wind element is pure.
If the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is originally empty, then how can those elements have purity?
There is also no anger or dispute.
If purity or dispute are both unobtainable, then what form is there that can be seen?

One should know that because the eye sense base is ultimately empty, its intrinsic nature is also empty. The past and future are both unobtainable, and what is created in the future is also unobtainable.
Why is this?
Because the intrinsic nature is detached.
If the intrinsic nature does not exist, then there is no male form and no female form. How can there be affection?
If affection arises, it is the realm of MÄra. If there is no affection, it is the realm of the Buddha.
Why is this?
If there is no affection, then one can be far removed from all dharmas.
Great King!
What is the ear sense base?
It is the pure form created by the four great elements, with distinctions and characteristics as explained before.
Great King!
All phenomena are liberated, definitely manifesting, like the empty Dharma realm that cannot be established.
Great King!
The various faculties each delight in their objects. When the eye encounters form, it gives rise to delight. Therefore, form is said to be the object of the eye.
Moreover, this eye faculty encounters form objects, with three kinds of characteristics:ğŸ”½When seeing attractive forms, it gives rise to thoughts of greed;
When seeing unattractive forms, it gives rise to thoughts of anger;
When seeing neither attractive nor unattractive forms, it gives rise to thoughts of indifference.

In the same way, up to the mind being attached to the sphere of mental objects becomes the object of the mind. If that mental object encounters attractive forms, it gives rise to extreme delight and is drawn to them, producing greedy actions;
When encountering unattractive forms, it gives rise to angry actions;
When encountering forms that are neither attractive nor unattractive, it produces deluded actions.
In the same way, the three kinds of objects such as sounds should be explained according to the previous [examples].
Great King!
The faculties are like an illusion, and the objects are like a dream. It is like a person who in a dream enjoys himself with various beautiful women.
Great King!
What do you think?
When that person awakens from the dream, would the pleasure he experienced be real or not?
The king said:
No, it is not.ğŸ”½
The Buddha said:
Great King!
Would that person who clings to his dream as real be considered wise or not?
No, it does not.ğŸ”½
World-Honored One!
Why is it so?

The beautiful women in the dream are ultimately non-existent, let alone enjoying oneself with them. One should know that this person who recalls the objects in the dream only tires himself in vain, and they cannot be obtained again.
The Buddha said:
Great King!
It is just like this!

Foolish beings, upon seeing forms with their eyes, give rise to attachment and further give rise to craving, being dragged along by it, they create karmic actions out of craving, with three kinds of physical actions, four kinds of verbal actions, and three kinds of mental actions.

As soon as they are created, they cease, and these karmic actions do not abide in the east, west, north, south, the four intermediate directions, above, below, or in between. At the end of life, when the life faculty ceases, one's own karmic retribution all appears before one, just like remembering things in a dream upon waking up.
Great King!

Consciousness is the master, and karmic actions are the conditions. These two kinds of causes give rise to the initial consciousness, which may lead to hell, or to rebirth as an animal, ghost, asura, human, or god.

After the initial consciousness arises, each receives their corresponding retribution, and the continuum of the homogeneous mental factors continues to evolve. The cessation of the final consciousness is called the aggregate of death, and the arising of the initial consciousness is called the aggregate of birth.
Great King!
There is not a single dharma that goes from this world to the next.
Why is this?
Because their nature is of arising and ceasing.
Great King!
When the body consciousness arises, it does not come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it does not go anywhere;
when that karma arises, it does not come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it does not go anywhere;
when the initial consciousness arises, it does not come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it does not go anywhere.
Why is this?
Because its intrinsic nature is of separation.

In this way, one understands that the body consciousness is empty of the body consciousness, one's own karma is empty of one's own karma, the initial consciousness is empty of the initial consciousness, cessation is empty of cessation, and arising is empty of arising. One understands that karma transforms without an agent or experiencer, but is merely conceptualized and displayed through names and forms.
Great King!
It is like a person who, in a dream, fights with enemies.
What do you think?
When that person awakens and recalls the events of the battle in the dream, are they real or not?
The king said:ğŸ”½No, World-Honored One.
No, it is not.
The Buddha said:
Great King!
Is the person who dreams and takes it as real considered wise?
The king said:
No, it is not.
World-Honored One!
Why is it so?
In a dream, there are ultimately no enemies, let alone fighting with them.
One should know that this person is just causing their own worry and distress, as it is all unreal.
The Buddha said:
Great King!
It is just like this!
Foolish ordinary beings, when their eyes see evil forms, they immediately give rise to vexation, aversion, destruction, slander, faults, and create the karmic actions of anger.

The three kinds of physical actions, the four kinds of verbal actions, and the three kinds of mental actions, as soon as they are created, immediately cease. These karmic actions do not abide in the east, west, south, north, the four intermediate directions, above, below, or in the middle. At the end of life, when the life faculty ceases, one's own karmic retribution all appears before one, just like remembering the events in a dream upon waking from sleep.
Great King!

Consciousness is the master, and karma is the condition. These two causes give rise to the first consciousness, which may lead to hell, or to rebirth as an animal, in the realm of Yama, or as an asura, human, or god.

After the first consciousness arises, each receives its corresponding retribution. The continuum of the same type of mind continues to evolve. The final moment of consciousness is called the aggregate at death, and the first moment of consciousness is called the aggregate at birth.
Great King!
There is not a single dharma that goes from this world to the next.
Why is this?
Because their nature is to arise and cease.
Great King!
When the body consciousness arises, it does not come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it does not go anywhere;
when that karma arises, it does not come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it does not go anywhere;
when the first consciousness arises, it does not come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it does not go anywhere.
Why is this?
Because it is devoid of intrinsic nature.

In this way, one understands that the body consciousness and body consciousness are empty, one's own karma and one's own karma are empty, the initial consciousness and initial consciousness are empty, if extinguished, extinction is empty, if born, birth is empty. One understands that karma transforms without an agent or experiencer, but is only nominally designated by conceptual discrimination.
Great King!
It is like a person who, in a dream, is disturbed and harmed by a piÅ›Äca, and gives rise to fear, delusion, and fainting.
Great King!
What do you think?
When this person awakens and remembers being disturbed by a ghost in the dream, is it really so?
The king said:
No, it is not so.ğŸ”½
The Buddha said:
Great King!
Is this person wise if he grasps what he dreamed as real?
The king said:
No, it is not.ğŸ”½
World-Honored One!
Why is it so?
In the dream, there were definitely no ghosts to disturb, so how could there be more delusion, fainting, and so forth?
You should know that such a person is just exhausting themselves and has no reality at all.
The Buddha said:
Great King!
It is just like this!
Foolish ordinary beings, with eyes seeing forms, are deluded and do not understand, creating deluded actions.

The three kinds of physical actions, the four kinds of verbal actions, and the three kinds of mental actions, as soon as they are created, instantly cease. When these actions cease, they do not abide in the east, south, west, north, the four intermediate directions, above or below, or in the middle. When the final moment of the life faculty ceases, one's own karmic retribution all appears before one, just like remembering events in a dream upon waking.
Great King!

Consciousness is the dominant factor, and karma is the condition. The two factors cause the initial consciousness to arise, leading to rebirth in the hells, as an animal, in the realm of Yama, as an asura, as a human, or as a god.

The first consciousness arises and each receives its retribution. The same class of mind continues to follow and transform. The final moment of consciousness ceasing is called the aggregate of death, and the first moment of consciousness arising is called the aggregate of birth.
Great King!
There is not a single dharma that goes from this world to the next world.
Why is this?
Because its nature is to arise and perish.
Great King!
When the body consciousness arises, it does not come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it does not go anywhere;
when that karma arises, it does not come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it does not go anywhere;
when the first consciousness arises, it does not come from anywhere, and when it ceases, it does not go anywhere.
Why is this?
Because it is inherently separated.

In this way, one understands that body consciousness is empty of body consciousness, one's own karma is empty of one's own karma, the first consciousness is empty of the first consciousness, cessation is empty of cessation, and arising is empty of arising.
One understands that karma transforms without an agent, and also without a receiver, but is merely manifested through the conceptualization of names and forms.
Great King!
One should know that the faculties are like an illusion and the objects are like a dream. All dharmas are completely empty and tranquil. This is called the door of liberation of emptiness.
Emptiness is devoid of the characteristics of emptiness, called the door of liberation of signlessness.
If there are no characteristics, then there is no aspiration, called the door of liberation of wishlessness.
